pageContext.claim: “[Modi] wants people to have religious freedom, and very strongly. And he said that in India they have -- they have worked very hard to have great and open religious freedom. And if you look back and look at what's going on, relative to other places especially, but they have really worked hard on religious freedom.”
pageContext.analysis: Modi has long had a tense relationship with India’s Muslim community. He joined a Hindu nationalist group as a young man and has been charged with turning a blind eye to riots that killed more than a thousand people — mostly Muslim — as Chief Minister of the Gujarati government in 2002. There's no evidence to suggest that his attitude toward religious diversity has changed.
